intro: Uvularia calcarata, commonly known as the rock violet, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, spurred flowers that resemble a small violet. The plant typically grows in rocky or wooded areas, preferring well-drained soil and partial shade. Its leaves are heart-shaped and have a rough texture, while its stems are often hairy. The blooming period occurs in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of pale blue or purple flowers.
